The '''Southern Asia Division (SUD) of Seventh-day Adventists''' is headquartered at [[Hosur]], [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]]. It heads the activities of the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]]es and its affiliated bodies in India, [[Nepal]] and [[Bhutan]].
The current division leadership was elected at [[General Conference Session]] held on 2010 in [[Atlanta|Atlanta,Georgia]] on 2010. John Rathinaraj<ref>[http://www.adventist.org.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=111:atlanta-news&catid=53:division-news&Itemid=60. Pastor John Rathinaraj. Adventist website for India.]</ref> was re-elected to serve as its President. On 2010, the Southern Asia Division of Seventh Day Adventists celebrated its 100 years of organized work as Division.
The affiliated bodies include [[List of Seventh-day Adventist colleges and universities#South Asia and Southwest Asia|educational institutions]] and [[List of Seventh-day Adventist hospitals#Southern Asia Division|medical institutions]] located all over India.
It is part of the [[General Conference of Seventh-day Adventists]], whose headquarters are located in [[Maryland]], [[United States]].
==History==
[[File:1898, India Adventist.JPG|215px|thumb|right|Church workers, 1898 in India. Click for list of people pictured.]] [[File:1912 YB India Union Mission.jpg|215px|thumb||right|Adventist work in Southern Asia, 1912]]
The Adventist presence in India began in the early 1890s. Progress was slow. By 1904, there were about 130 Adventists there.<ref name = "Outline" >{{Cite book | last = | first = | title = Empire of India in An Outline of Mission Fields entered by Seventh-day Adventists, fourth edition | publisher = Mission Board of Seventh-day Adventists | year = 1920 | location = Washington, D.C. | pages = 112â122 | url = http://www.archive.org/stream/MN41448ucmf_6#page/n115/mode/2up/search/%22empire+of+india%22 | isbn = }}</ref> The church began with book sales and pamphlet distribution. Early endeavors also included medical work, schools, care of orphans, and [[zenana]] work. At first, converts were of European heritage. There were some among the Indian population. One of them, A. C. Mookerjee. He was the grandson of [[William Carey|William Carey's]] first convert. <ref name = "Spalding3" >{{Cite book | last = Spalding | first = Arthur Whitefield | title = Origin and History, Volume 3 | publisher = Review and Herald Publishing Association | year = 1962 | location = Washington, D.C. | url = http://www.adventistarchives.org/docs/OH/OH1962-03__B.pdf#view=fit | isbn = }} pages 108-109.</ref>
In 1900 the mission director, D. A. Robinson, died from smallpox. [[William A. Spicer]], at thirty-five years old, became the director. He was editor of the Oriental Watchman, the first Adventist periodical to be published in a completely non-Christian land. His leadership of the field was brief. In 1901, while attending the General Conference, Spicer was appointed as the secretary of the Foreign Mission Board located in the United States. [[John Luis Shaw|John L. Shaw]] took over the leadership of the India field. Shaw came from the principalship of the church's South African school at Cape Town. With a few brief absences, he remained in India for twenty-three years.<ref name = "Spalding3" />
The first of the Seventh-day Adventist Mission Quarterlies focused on the need for evangelism in India's major cities.Many people of India, still under British rule, spoke English. The 1912 Quarterly included a thrice repeated appeal from Shaw. He emphasized the need for missionaries who could preach in English.<ref name = "Quarterly">{{Cite journal | title = A New Plan | journal = Mission Quarterly | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 1â8 | date = June 29, 1912 | url = http://www.adventistarchives.org/docs/MQ/MQ19120629-V04-01__C.pdf#view=fit }} </ref>
In 1912, five Adventist missions formed the organization of the India field: North India, West India, South India, Bengal and Burma. (See the map to the right.)
